memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2567

TITLE OF BILL:

An act to amend the alcoholic beverage control law, in relation to
penalties for violations thereof

SUMMARY:

This would amend subdivision one of § 130 to the alcoholic beverage
control law which determines the fines associated with any person who
manufactures for sale or sells alcoholic beverages without the appropri-
ate license.

JUSTIFICATION:

Public hearings held by the Senate Minority Task Force on Criminal
Justice in 1981, determined that there are a myriad of illegal social
clubs operating throughout the State. Legislation resulting from these
hearings created specific penalties for involvement in the manufacturing
for sale or selling of alcoholic beverages without a proper liquor
license.

As a result of the recent tragedy in the Bronx, it appears the current
statutes are not a great enough deterrent for individuals to become
involved with illicit social clubs. Currently, upon first conviction
there is a punishment of not more than two times the cost of a liquor
license. This legislation increases the fines for persons who neglect to
obtain a legal liquor license and yet participate in the sale of alco-
holic beverages. Upon first conviction the person shall be punished by a
fine of three times the cost of a special three year on-premise liquor
license. All subsequent convictions shall be subject to a fine of five
times the cost of a three year on premise liquor license.

Three year on-premise liquor licenses range from $700 to $5,100. The
multiple cost of the license, calculated as a fine, should restore the
deterrent factor for individuals involved with illegal social clubs.

FISCAL IMPLICATION:

None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

The first day of November next succeeding the date on which it shall
have become a law.
